Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: It was already past 7 p.m. when I finally glanced at my phone and saw a message from Mom: “Can you call when you have a minute?” I knew she and Dad had been arguing more lately, and I’d promised myself I’d check in on them regularly. I could almost hear her voice, hoping for reassurance, for me to ask if everything was okay at home. But my laptop screen glared back at me, the unfinished report blinking like an accusation. The deadline was tomorrow morning, and if I didn’t finish, the next part of the project—Sarah’s section—would be delayed, throwing off the whole team. I could already imagine the disappointment in my manager’s eyes, the subtle frustration from my colleagues. My parents needed me to be present, to listen, to care. My team needed me to deliver, to be reliable. I sat there, torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down, unsure which expectation I could bear to let down.
